[File: aptos-core/storage/db-tool/src/bootstrap.rs] [Function: load_genesis_txn()] [Path Traversal] Can an attacker provide a malicious genesis_txn_file path using directory traversal sequences (../../etc/passwd) to read arbitrary system files and leak sensitive validator keys or configuration data? (High)

[File: aptos-core/storage/db-tool/src/bootstrap.rs] [Function: load_genesis_txn()] [Symlink Attack] Can an attacker create a symbolic link pointing to sensitive files and trick the bootstrapper into loading arbitrary file contents as genesis transaction, potentially causing state corruption or information disclosure? (High)

[File: aptos-core/storage/db-tool/src/bootstrap.rs] [Function: load_genesis_txn()] [Memory Exhaustion] Does the file.read_to_end(&mut buffer) operation impose any size limits, or can an attacker provide an extremely large genesis file (gigabytes) to cause memory exhaustion and crash validator nodes during bootstrapping? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/storage/db-tool/src/bootstrap.rs] [Function: load_genesis_txn()] [BCS Deserialization Attack] Can a maliciously crafted BCS-encoded file exploit vulnerabilities in bcs::from_bytes() to cause panic, infinite loops, or memory corruption during deserialization of nested structures? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/storage/db-tool/src/bootstrap.rs] [Function: load_genesis_txn()] [Type Confusion] After BCS deserialization returns a Transaction object, can an attacker craft a file that deserializes to a non-GenesisTransaction variant (UserTransaction, BlockMetadata) but passes the assertion check through type confusion? (High)

[File: aptos-core/storage/db-tool/src/bootstrap.rs] [Function: load_genesis_txn()] [Integer Overflow] Can an attacker craft a BCS payload with extremely large length prefixes that cause integer overflow in buffer allocation during deserialization, leading to heap corruption? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/storage/db-tool/src/bootstrap.rs] [Function: load_genesis_txn()] [Resource Exhaustion] Does the BCS deserializer have recursion depth limits, or can deeply nested Transaction structures cause stack overflow during deserialization? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/storage/db-tool/src/bootstrap.rs] [Function: load_genesis_txn()] [Race Condition] If the genesis file is modified between the File::open() call and read_to_end() operation (TOCTOU), can an attacker swap the file contents to inject a malicious genesis transaction? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/storage/db-tool/src/bootstrap.rs] [Function: Command::run()] [Transaction Type Bypass] The assertion at line 45-47 only checks if the transaction matches GenesisTransaction pattern - can an attacker craft a GenesisTransaction with malicious WriteSetPayload that bypasses validation in calculate_genesis()? [File: aptos-core/storage/db-tool/src/bootstrap.rs] [Function: Command::run()] [Empty Genesis] What happens if the genesis_txn contains an empty WriteSet - does calculate_genesis() properly reject it, or could it create a blockchain with uninitialized state allowing fund creation from nothing? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/storage/db-tool/src/bootstrap.rs] [Function: Command::run()] [Malicious State Initialization] Can the genesis transaction WriteSet initialize system accounts (0x1, 0x2) with arbitrary balances or permissions that violate economic security invariants? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/storage/db-tool/src/bootstrap.rs] [Function: Command::run()] [Resource Duplication] Can a malicious genesis WriteSet create duplicate resource instances that violate Move's resource uniqueness guarantees, enabling double-spending at genesis? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/storage/db-tool/src/bootstrap.rs] [Function: Command::run()] [Concurrent Access] The comment at line 50-51 states the DB is opened exclusively, but does AptosDB::open() actually acquire file-level locks, or can multiple bootstrap processes run concurrently causing database corruption? [File: aptos-core/storage/db-tool/src/bootstrap.rs] [Function: Command::run()] [Lock Bypass] If the database is already locked by a running node, does the .expect() panic at line 62 leave the database in an inconsistent state, or is there proper cleanup? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/storage/db-tool/src/bootstrap.rs] [Function: Command::run()] [Directory Traversal in db_dir] Can an attacker provide a malicious db_dir path that writes genesis data to arbitrary filesystem locations through path traversal, potentially overwriting critical system files? (High)

[File: aptos-core/storage/db-tool/src/bootstrap.rs] [Function: Command::run()] [Symlink Attack on db_dir] Can an attacker create symbolic links in the db_dir path to redirect database writes to sensitive locations or cause denial of service? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/storage/db-tool/src/bootstrap.rs] [Function: Command::run()] [Storage Configuration Attack] The NO_OP_STORAGE_PRUNER_CONFIG is hardcoded at line 55 - could this lead to unbounded database growth during genesis calculation if an attacker provides a genesis transaction that generates massive state? [File: aptos-core/storage/db-tool/src/bootstrap.rs] [Function: Command::run()] [Configuration Injection] Can an attacker manipulate BUFFERED_STATE_TARGET_ITEMS or DEFAULT_MAX_NUM_NODES_PER_LRU_CACHE_SHARD through environment variables to cause memory exhaustion or performance degradation? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/storage/db-tool/src/bootstrap.rs] [Function: Command::run()] [Indexer Disabled] The indexer parameter is set to false at line 57 - does this mean the genesis state cannot be properly queried after bootstrapping, potentially breaking API functionality? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/storage/db-tool/src/bootstrap.rs] [Function: Command::run()] [Version Confusion] At line 65-68, get_pre_committed_ledger_summary() is called - if the database has uncommitted transactions in memory, could there be a mismatch between pre-committed and actual state causing waypoint verification to pass with wrong state? [File: aptos-core/storage/db-tool/src/bootstrap.rs] [Function: Command::run()] [Integer Overflow in Version Check] At line 72, waypoint.version() is compared to ledger_summary.next_version() - can integer overflow occur if next_version() returns u64::MAX, causing the comparison to incorrectly succeed? [File: aptos-core/storage/db-tool/src/bootstrap.rs] [Function: Command::run()] [Off-by-One Version Error] The check at line 72 compares waypoint.version() == ledger_summary.next_version() - is this correct, or should it be next_version() - 1? Could this allow applying genesis at wrong versions? (High)

[File: aptos-core/storage/db-tool/src/bootstrap.rs] [Function: Command::run()] [Non-Empty Database Attack] If the database already has transactions (next_version() > 0), what prevents an attacker from providing a genesis transaction that conflicts with existing state, causing irreversible state corruption? [File: aptos-core/storage/db-tool/src/bootstrap.rs] [Function: Command::run()] [Genesis Replay] Can the same genesis transaction be applied multiple times if calculate_genesis() is called repeatedly with the same ledger_summary, potentially duplicating state or violating idempotency? (High)
